(+); no data – but Swann (1950: 58) notes that ridges and trenches where seeds were sown were alternated
experiments of lending grain to farmers in bad years
licenses salt production [underlined]; as of 119 B.C.
also within the society, to balance prices and later as a source of revenue
agriculture [underlined]; Director of Agriculture, Grand Ceremonialist, Commandant of Justice
The Grand Herald dealt with submitted barbarians and feudal lords
Han China did in fact have fully differentiated officials who were full-time specialists in the administration of justice
Evidence of guilt often extorted by bastinado
The Grand Administrator did this as the ruler’s agent

(+); property acquired in excess of the sumptuary laws, or gotten by illegal means, was confiscated with a vengeance. Corporal punishment was also commutable, in some cases, with fines amounting to confiscation
But NB: incarceration was only temporary pending final disposition of a case. It was not in itself a full punishment
still practiced surreptitiously, but officially frowned on
This is evident from the excellence of funerary reliefs found in tombs of minor nobility
Guardian statues before tombs. Diffusion from west is suggested
imported from Rome until late in the period
counterweight for raising water from a well
cited in the Huai Nan Tzu (2nd C. B.C.)
instituted by the first emperor of Ch’in for all China
(-); not a strong Chinese trait until Sung time
